KYLE MYERS: I study the
economics of science.

My work focuses on the ways in
which the market for science

does a good or bad
job of turning ideas
into applications.

My goal is to better understand
how scientists choose

their pursuits and, in turn,
how managers and policies can

be used to influence the
direction of innovation.

One of the organizations that
I spend a lot of time studying

is the US National Institutes
of Health, the NIH.

It's the largest funder
of biomedical research
in the world.

I've worked with data from the
NIH to study questions like,

how can grant funding be used to
incentivize scientists to shift

the direction of
their work, and also,

how well does the
NIH investments

into small businesses
translate into

new biomedical
technologies that wouldn't
have been invented otherwise?

Hopefully, by becoming
familiar with the structures

and incentives facing
scientists today

while also developing skills
and frameworks for managing

those scientists
and their ideas,

we can better understand how
to improve the rate of progress
in the future.
